trans-unit.source: Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Client-Side Encryption for Microsoft Azure Storage | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage Client Library for .NET supports client-side encryption and integration with Azure Key Vault for maximum security for your Azure Storage applications.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage Client Library for .NET supports client-side encryption and integration with Azure Key Vault for maximum security for your Azure Storage applications.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title> supports encrypting data within client applications before uploading to Azure Storage, and decrypting data while downloading to the client.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>Azure Storage Client Library for .NET</linkText><title></title> supports encrypting data within client applications before uploading to Azure Storage, and decrypting data while downloading to the client.

trans-unit.source: The library also supports integration with <linkText>Azure Key Vault</linkText><title></title> for storage account key management.
trans-unit.target: The library also supports integration with <linkText>Azure Key Vault</linkText><title></title> for storage account key management.

trans-unit.source: The processes of encryption and decryption follow the envelope technique.
trans-unit.target: The processes of encryption and decryption follow the envelope technique.

trans-unit.source: Encryption via the envelope technique works in the following way:
trans-unit.target: Encryption via the envelope technique works in the following way:

trans-unit.source: The Azure storage client library generates a content encryption key (CEK), which is a one-time-use symmetric key.
trans-unit.target: The Azure storage client library generates a content encryption key (CEK), which is a one-time-use symmetric key.

trans-unit.source: User data is encrypted using this CEK.
trans-unit.target: User data is encrypted using this CEK.

trans-unit.source: The CEK is then wrapped (encrypted) using the key encryption key (KEK).
trans-unit.target: The CEK is then wrapped (encrypted) using the key encryption key (KEK).

trans-unit.source: The KEK is identified by a key identifier and can be an asymmetric key pair or a symmetric key and can be managed locally or stored in Azure Key Vaults.
trans-unit.target: The KEK is identified by a key identifier and can be an asymmetric key pair or a symmetric key and can be managed locally or stored in Azure Key Vaults.

trans-unit.source: The storage client library itself never has access to KEK.
trans-unit.target: The storage client library itself never has access to KEK.

trans-unit.source: The library invokes the key wrapping algorithm that is provided by Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: The library invokes the key wrapping algorithm that is provided by Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Users can choose to use custom providers for key wrapping/unwrapping if desired.
trans-unit.target: Users can choose to use custom providers for key wrapping/unwrapping if desired.

trans-unit.source: The encrypted data is then uploaded to the Azure Storage service.
trans-unit.target: The encrypted data is then uploaded to the Azure Storage service.

trans-unit.source: The wrapped key along with some additional encryption metadata is either stored as metadata (on a blob) or interpolated with the encrypted data (queue messages and table entities).
trans-unit.target: The wrapped key along with some additional encryption metadata is either stored as metadata (on a blob) or interpolated with the encrypted data (queue messages and table entities).

trans-unit.source: Decryption via the envelope technique works in the following way:
trans-unit.target: Decryption via the envelope technique works in the following way:

trans-unit.source: The client library assumes that the user is managing the key encryption key (KEK) either locally or in Azure Key Vaults.
trans-unit.target: The client library assumes that the user is managing the key encryption key (KEK) either locally or in Azure Key Vaults.

trans-unit.source: The user does not need to know the specific key that was used for encryption.
trans-unit.target: The user does not need to know the specific key that was used for encryption.

trans-unit.source: Instead, a key resolver which resolves different key identifiers to keys can be set up and used.
trans-unit.target: Instead, a key resolver which resolves different key identifiers to keys can be set up and used.

trans-unit.source: The client library downloads the encrypted data along with any encryption material that is stored on the service.
trans-unit.target: The client library downloads the encrypted data along with any encryption material that is stored on the service.

trans-unit.source: The wrapped content encryption key (CEK) is then unwrapped (decrypted) using the key encryption key (KEK).
trans-unit.target: The wrapped content encryption key (CEK) is then unwrapped (decrypted) using the key encryption key (KEK).

trans-unit.source: Here again, the client library does not have access to KEK.
trans-unit.target: Here again, the client library does not have access to KEK.

trans-unit.source: It simply invokes the custom or Key Vault provider’s unwrapping algorithm.
trans-unit.target: It simply invokes the custom or Key Vault provider’s unwrapping algorithm.

trans-unit.source: The content encryption key (CEK) is then used to decrypt the encrypted user data.
trans-unit.target: The content encryption key (CEK) is then used to decrypt the encrypted user data.

trans-unit.source: The storage client library uses [AES](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AdvancedEncryptionStandard) in order to encrypt user data.
trans-unit.target: The storage client library uses [AES](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AdvancedEncryptionStandard) in order to encrypt user data.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, [Cipher Block Chaining (CBC)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockciphermodeofoperation#Cipher-blockchaining.28CBC.29) mode with AES.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, [Cipher Block Chaining (CBC)](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockciphermodeofoperation#Cipher-blockchaining.28CBC.29) mode with AES.

trans-unit.source: Each service works somewhat differently, so we will discuss each of them here.
trans-unit.target: Each service works somewhat differently, so we will discuss each of them here.

trans-unit.source: The client library currently supports encryption of whole blobs only.
trans-unit.target: The client library currently supports encryption of whole blobs only.

trans-unit.source: Specifically, encryption is supported when users use the UploadFrom* methods or the OpenWrite method.
trans-unit.target: Specifically, encryption is supported when users use the UploadFrom* methods or the OpenWrite method.

trans-unit.source: For downloads, both complete and range downloads are supported.
trans-unit.target: For downloads, both complete and range downloads are supported.

trans-unit.source: During encryption, the client library will generate a random Initialization Vector (IV) of 16 bytes, together with a random content encryption key (CEK) of 32 bytes, and perform envelope encryption of the blob data using this information.
trans-unit.target: During encryption, the client library will generate a random Initialization Vector (IV) of 16 bytes, together with a random content encryption key (CEK) of 32 bytes, and perform envelope encryption of the blob data using this information.

trans-unit.source: The wrapped CEK and some additional encryption metadata are then stored as blob metadata along with the encrypted blob on the service.
trans-unit.target: The wrapped CEK and some additional encryption metadata are then stored as blob metadata along with the encrypted blob on the service.

trans-unit.source: If you are editing or uploading your own metadata for the blob, you need to ensure that this metadata is preserved.
trans-unit.target: If you are editing or uploading your own metadata for the blob, you need to ensure that this metadata is preserved.

trans-unit.source: If you upload new metadata without this metadata, the wrapped CEK, IV and other metadata will be lost and the blob content will never be retrievable again.
trans-unit.target: If you upload new metadata without this metadata, the wrapped CEK, IV and other metadata will be lost and the blob content will never be retrievable again.

trans-unit.source: Downloading an encrypted blob involves retrieving the content of the entire blob using the DownloadTo*/BlobReadStream convenience methods.
trans-unit.target: Downloading an encrypted blob involves retrieving the content of the entire blob using the DownloadTo*/BlobReadStream convenience methods.

trans-unit.source: The wrapped CEK is unwrapped and used together with the IV (stored as blob metadata in this case) to return the decrypted data to the users.
trans-unit.target: The wrapped CEK is unwrapped and used together with the IV (stored as blob metadata in this case) to return the decrypted data to the users.

trans-unit.source: Downloading an arbitrary range (DownloadRange* methods) in the encrypted blob involves adjusting the range provided by users in order to get a small amount of additional data that can be used to successfully decrypt the requested range.
trans-unit.target: Downloading an arbitrary range (DownloadRange* methods) in the encrypted blob involves adjusting the range provided by users in order to get a small amount of additional data that can be used to successfully decrypt the requested range.

trans-unit.source: All blob types (block blobs, page blobs, and append blobs) can be encrypted/decrypted using this scheme.
trans-unit.target: All blob types (block blobs, page blobs, and append blobs) can be encrypted/decrypted using this scheme.

trans-unit.source: Since queue messages can be of any format, the client library defines a custom format that includes the Initialization Vector (IV) and the encrypted content encryption key (CEK) in the message text.
trans-unit.target: Since queue messages can be of any format, the client library defines a custom format that includes the Initialization Vector (IV) and the encrypted content encryption key (CEK) in the message text.

trans-unit.source: During encryption, the client library generates a random IV of 16 bytes along with a random CEK of 32 bytes and performs envelope encryption of the queue message text using this information.
trans-unit.target: During encryption, the client library generates a random IV of 16 bytes along with a random CEK of 32 bytes and performs envelope encryption of the queue message text using this information.

trans-unit.source: The wrapped CEK and some additional encryption metadata are then added to the encrypted queue message.
trans-unit.target: The wrapped CEK and some additional encryption metadata are then added to the encrypted queue message.

trans-unit.source: This modified message (shown below) is stored on the service.
trans-unit.target: This modified message (shown below) is stored on the service.

trans-unit.source: During decryption, the wrapped key is extracted from the queue message and unwrapped.
trans-unit.target: During decryption, the wrapped key is extracted from the queue message and unwrapped.

trans-unit.source: The IV is also extracted from the queue message and used along with the unwrapped key to decrypt the queue message data.
trans-unit.target: The IV is also extracted from the queue message and used along with the unwrapped key to decrypt the queue message data.

trans-unit.source: Note that the encryption metadata is small (under 500 bytes), so while it does count toward the 64KB limit for a queue message, the impact should be manageable.
trans-unit.target: Note that the encryption metadata is small (under 500 bytes), so while it does count toward the 64KB limit for a queue message, the impact should be manageable.

trans-unit.source: The client library supports encryption of entity properties for insert and replace operations.
trans-unit.target: The client library supports encryption of entity properties for insert and replace operations.

trans-unit.source: Merge is not currently supported.
trans-unit.target: Merge is not currently supported.

trans-unit.source: Since a subset of properties may have been encrypted previously using a different key, simply merging the new properties and updating the metadata will result in data loss.
trans-unit.target: Since a subset of properties may have been encrypted previously using a different key, simply merging the new properties and updating the metadata will result in data loss.

trans-unit.source: Merging either requires making extra service calls to read the pre-existing entity from the service, or using a new key per property, both of which are not suitable for performance reasons.
trans-unit.target: Merging either requires making extra service calls to read the pre-existing entity from the service, or using a new key per property, both of which are not suitable for performance reasons.

trans-unit.source: Table data encryption works as follows:
trans-unit.target: Table data encryption works as follows:

trans-unit.source: Users specify the properties to be encrypted.
trans-unit.target: Users specify the properties to be encrypted.

trans-unit.source: The client library generates a random Initialization Vector (IV) of 16 bytes along with a random content encryption key (CEK) of 32 bytes for every entity, and performs envelope encryption on the individual properties to be encrypted by deriving a new IV per property.
trans-unit.target: The client library generates a random Initialization Vector (IV) of 16 bytes along with a random content encryption key (CEK) of 32 bytes for every entity, and performs envelope encryption on the individual properties to be encrypted by deriving a new IV per property.

trans-unit.source: The encrypted property is stored as binary data.
trans-unit.target: The encrypted property is stored as binary data.

trans-unit.source: The wrapped CEK and some additional encryption metadata are then stored as two additional reserved properties.
trans-unit.target: The wrapped CEK and some additional encryption metadata are then stored as two additional reserved properties.

trans-unit.source: The first reserved property (_ClientEncryptionMetadata1) is a string property that holds the information about IV, version, and wrapped key.
trans-unit.target: The first reserved property (_ClientEncryptionMetadata1) is a string property that holds the information about IV, version, and wrapped key.

trans-unit.source: The second reserved property (_ClientEncryptionMetadata2) is a binary property that holds the information about the properties that are encrypted.
trans-unit.target: The second reserved property (_ClientEncryptionMetadata2) is a binary property that holds the information about the properties that are encrypted.

trans-unit.source: The information in this second property (_ClientEncryptionMetadata2) is itself encrypted.
trans-unit.target: The information in this second property (_ClientEncryptionMetadata2) is itself encrypted.

trans-unit.source: Due to these additional reserved properties required for encryption, users may now have only 250 custom properties instead of 252.
trans-unit.target: Due to these additional reserved properties required for encryption, users may now have only 250 custom properties instead of 252.

trans-unit.source: The total size of the entity must be less than 1MB.
trans-unit.target: The total size of the entity must be less than 1MB.

trans-unit.source: Note that only string properties can be encrypted.
trans-unit.target: Note that only string properties can be encrypted.

trans-unit.source: If other types of properties are to be encrypted, they must be converted to strings.
trans-unit.target: If other types of properties are to be encrypted, they must be converted to strings.

trans-unit.source: The encrypted strings are stored on the service as binary properties, and they are converted back to strings after decryption.
trans-unit.target: The encrypted strings are stored on the service as binary properties, and they are converted back to strings after decryption.

trans-unit.source: For tables, in addition to the encryption policy, users must specify the properties to be encrypted.
trans-unit.target: For tables, in addition to the encryption policy, users must specify the properties to be encrypted.

trans-unit.source: This can be done by either specifying an [EncryptProperty] attribute (for POCO entities that derive from TableEntity) or an encryption resolver in request options.
trans-unit.target: This can be done by either specifying an [EncryptProperty] attribute (for POCO entities that derive from TableEntity) or an encryption resolver in request options.

trans-unit.source: An encryption resolver is a delegate that takes a partition key, row key, and property name and returns a Boolean that indicates whether that property should be encrypted.
trans-unit.target: An encryption resolver is a delegate that takes a partition key, row key, and property name and returns a Boolean that indicates whether that property should be encrypted.

trans-unit.source: During encryption, the client library will use this information to decide whether a property should be encrypted while writing to the wire.
trans-unit.target: During encryption, the client library will use this information to decide whether a property should be encrypted while writing to the wire.

trans-unit.source: The delegate also provides for the possibility of logic around how properties are encrypted.
trans-unit.target: The delegate also provides for the possibility of logic around how properties are encrypted.

trans-unit.source: (For example, if X, then encrypt property A; otherwise encrypt properties A and B.)
trans-unit.target: (For example, if X, then encrypt property A; otherwise encrypt properties A and B.)

trans-unit.source: Note that it is not necessary to provide this information while reading or querying entities.
trans-unit.target: Note that it is not necessary to provide this information while reading or querying entities.

trans-unit.source: In batch operations, the same KEK will be used across all the rows in that batch operation because the client library only allows one options object (and hence one policy/KEK) per batch operation.
trans-unit.target: In batch operations, the same KEK will be used across all the rows in that batch operation because the client library only allows one options object (and hence one policy/KEK) per batch operation.

trans-unit.source: However, the client library will internally generate a new random IV and random CEK per row in the batch.
trans-unit.target: However, the client library will internally generate a new random IV and random CEK per row in the batch.

trans-unit.source: Users can also choose to encrypt different properties for every operation in the batch by defining this behavior in the encryption resolver.
trans-unit.target: Users can also choose to encrypt different properties for every operation in the batch by defining this behavior in the encryption resolver.

trans-unit.source: To perform query operations, you must specify a key resolver that is able to resolve all the keys in the result set.
trans-unit.target: To perform query operations, you must specify a key resolver that is able to resolve all the keys in the result set.

trans-unit.source: If an entity contained in the query result cannot be resolved to a provider, the client library will throw an error.
trans-unit.target: If an entity contained in the query result cannot be resolved to a provider, the client library will throw an error.

trans-unit.source: For any query that performs server side projections, the client library will add the special encryption metadata properties (_ClientEncryptionMetadata1 and _ClientEncryptionMetadata2) by default to the selected columns.
trans-unit.target: For any query that performs server side projections, the client library will add the special encryption metadata properties (_ClientEncryptionMetadata1 and _ClientEncryptionMetadata2) by default to the selected columns.

trans-unit.source: Azure Key Vault helps safeguard cryptographic keys and secrets used by cloud applications and services.
trans-unit.target: Azure Key Vault helps safeguard cryptographic keys and secrets used by cloud applications and services.

trans-unit.source: By using Azure Key Vault, users can encrypt keys and secrets (such as authentication keys, storage account keys, data encryption keys, .PFX files, and passwords) by using keys that are protected by hardware security modules (HSMs).
trans-unit.target: By using Azure Key Vault, users can encrypt keys and secrets (such as authentication keys, storage account keys, data encryption keys, .PFX files, and passwords) by using keys that are protected by hardware security modules (HSMs).

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>What is Azure Key Vault?</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>What is Azure Key Vault?</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The storage client library uses the Key Vault core library in order to provide a common framework across Azure for managing keys.
trans-unit.target: The storage client library uses the Key Vault core library in order to provide a common framework across Azure for managing keys.

trans-unit.source: Users also get the additional benefit of using the Key Vault extensions library.
trans-unit.target: Users also get the additional benefit of using the Key Vault extensions library.

trans-unit.source: The extensions library provides useful functionality around simple and seamless Symmetric/RSA local and cloud key providers as well as with aggregation and caching.
trans-unit.target: The extensions library provides useful functionality around simple and seamless Symmetric/RSA local and cloud key providers as well as with aggregation and caching.

trans-unit.source: There are three Key Vault packages:
trans-unit.target: There are three Key Vault packages:

trans-unit.source: Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault.Core contains the IKey and IKeyResolver.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault.Core contains the IKey and IKeyResolver.

trans-unit.source: It is a small package with no dependencies.
trans-unit.target: It is a small package with no dependencies.

trans-unit.source: The storage client library for .NET defines it as a dependency.
trans-unit.target: The storage client library for .NET defines it as a dependency.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault contains the Key Vault REST client.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault contains the Key Vault REST client.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault.Extensions contains extension code that includes implementations of cryptographic algorithms and an RSAKey and a SymmetricKey.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft.Azure.KeyVault.Extensions contains extension code that includes implementations of cryptographic algorithms and an RSAKey and a SymmetricKey.

trans-unit.source: It depends on the Core and KeyVault namespaces and provides functionality to define an aggregate resolver (when users want to use multiple key providers) and a caching key resolver.
trans-unit.target: It depends on the Core and KeyVault namespaces and provides functionality to define an aggregate resolver (when users want to use multiple key providers) and a caching key resolver.

trans-unit.source: Although the storage client library does not directly depend on this package, if users wish to use Azure Key Vault to store their keys or to use the Key Vault extensions to consume the local and cloud cryptographic providers, they will need this package.
trans-unit.target: Although the storage client library does not directly depend on this package, if users wish to use Azure Key Vault to store their keys or to use the Key Vault extensions to consume the local and cloud cryptographic providers, they will need this package.

trans-unit.source: Key Vault is designed for high-value master keys, and throttling limits per Key Vault are designed with this in mind.
trans-unit.target: Key Vault is designed for high-value master keys, and throttling limits per Key Vault are designed with this in mind.

trans-unit.source: When performing client-side encryption with Key Vault, the preferred model is to use symmetric master keys stored as secrets in Key Vault and cached locally.
trans-unit.target: When performing client-side encryption with Key Vault, the preferred model is to use symmetric master keys stored as secrets in Key Vault and cached locally.

trans-unit.source: Users must do the following:
trans-unit.target: Users must do the following:

trans-unit.source: Create a secret offline and upload it to Key Vault.
trans-unit.target: Create a secret offline and upload it to Key Vault.

trans-unit.source: Use the secret's base identifier as a parameter to resolve the current version of the secret for encryption and cache this information locally.
trans-unit.target: Use the secret's base identifier as a parameter to resolve the current version of the secret for encryption and cache this information locally.

trans-unit.source: Use CachingKeyResolver for caching; users are not expected to implement their own caching logic.
trans-unit.target: Use CachingKeyResolver for caching; users are not expected to implement their own caching logic.

trans-unit.source: Use the caching resolver as an input while creating the encryption policy.
trans-unit.target: Use the caching resolver as an input while creating the encryption policy.

trans-unit.source: More information regarding Key Vault usage can be found in the <linkText>encryption code samples</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: More information regarding Key Vault usage can be found in the <linkText>encryption code samples</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Encryption support is available only in the storage client library for .NET.
trans-unit.target: Encryption support is available only in the storage client library for .NET.

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone and Windows Runtime do not currently support encryption.
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone and Windows Runtime do not currently support encryption.

trans-unit.source: Be aware of these important points when using client-side encryption:
trans-unit.target: Be aware of these important points when using client-side encryption:

trans-unit.source: When reading from or writing to an encrypted blob, use whole blob upload commands and range/whole blob download commands.
trans-unit.target: When reading from or writing to an encrypted blob, use whole blob upload commands and range/whole blob download commands.

trans-unit.source: Avoid writing to an encrypted blob using protocol operations such as Put Block, Put Block List, Write Pages, Clear Pages, or Append Block; otherwise you may corrupt the encrypted blob and make it unreadable.
trans-unit.target: Avoid writing to an encrypted blob using protocol operations such as Put Block, Put Block List, Write Pages, Clear Pages, or Append Block; otherwise you may corrupt the encrypted blob and make it unreadable.

trans-unit.source: For tables, a similar constraint exists.
trans-unit.target: For tables, a similar constraint exists.

trans-unit.source: Be careful to not update encrypted properties without updating the encryption metadata.
trans-unit.target: Be careful to not update encrypted properties without updating the encryption metadata.

trans-unit.source: If you set metadata on the encrypted blob, you may overwrite the encryption-related metadata required for decryption, since setting metadata is not additive.
trans-unit.target: If you set metadata on the encrypted blob, you may overwrite the encryption-related metadata required for decryption, since setting metadata is not additive.

trans-unit.source: This is also true for snapshots; avoid specifying metadata while creating a snapshot of an encrypted blob.
trans-unit.target: This is also true for snapshots; avoid specifying metadata while creating a snapshot of an encrypted blob.

trans-unit.source: If metadata must be set, be sure to call the FetchAttributes method first to get the current encryption metadata, and avoid concurrent writes while metadata is being set.
trans-unit.target: If metadata must be set, be sure to call the FetchAttributes method first to get the current encryption metadata, and avoid concurrent writes while metadata is being set.

trans-unit.source: Enable the RequireEncryption property in the default request options for users that should work only with encrypted data.
trans-unit.target: Enable the RequireEncryption property in the default request options for users that should work only with encrypted data.

trans-unit.source: See below for more info.
trans-unit.target: See below for more info.

trans-unit.source: While creating an EncryptionPolicy object, users can provide only a Key (implementing IKey), only a resolver (implementing IKeyResolver), or both.
trans-unit.target: While creating an EncryptionPolicy object, users can provide only a Key (implementing IKey), only a resolver (implementing IKeyResolver), or both.

trans-unit.source: IKey is the basic key type that is identified using a key identifier and that provides the logic for wrapping/unwrapping.
trans-unit.target: IKey is the basic key type that is identified using a key identifier and that provides the logic for wrapping/unwrapping.

trans-unit.source: IKeyResolver is used to resolve a key during the decryption process.
trans-unit.target: IKeyResolver is used to resolve a key during the decryption process.

trans-unit.source: It defines a ResolveKey method that returns an IKey given a key identifier.
trans-unit.target: It defines a ResolveKey method that returns an IKey given a key identifier.

trans-unit.source: This provides users the ability to choose between multiple keys that are managed in multiple locations.
trans-unit.target: This provides users the ability to choose between multiple keys that are managed in multiple locations.

trans-unit.source: For encryption, the key is used always and the absence of a key will result in an error.
trans-unit.target: For encryption, the key is used always and the absence of a key will result in an error.

trans-unit.source: For decryption:
trans-unit.target: For decryption:

trans-unit.source: The key resolver is invoked if specified to get the key.
trans-unit.target: The key resolver is invoked if specified to get the key.

trans-unit.source: If the resolver is specified but does not have a mapping for the key identifier, an error is thrown.
trans-unit.target: If the resolver is specified but does not have a mapping for the key identifier, an error is thrown.

trans-unit.source: If resolver is not specified but a key is specified, the key is used if its identifier matches the required key identifier.
trans-unit.target: If resolver is not specified but a key is specified, the key is used if its identifier matches the required key identifier.

trans-unit.source: If the identifier does not match, an error is thrown.
trans-unit.target: If the identifier does not match, an error is thrown.

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>encryption samples</linkText><title></title> demonstrate a more detailed end-to-end scenario for blobs, queues and tables, along with Key Vault integration.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>encryption samples</linkText><title></title> demonstrate a more detailed end-to-end scenario for blobs, queues and tables, along with Key Vault integration.

trans-unit.source: Users can optionally enable a mode of operation where all uploads and downloads must be encrypted.
trans-unit.target: Users can optionally enable a mode of operation where all uploads and downloads must be encrypted.

trans-unit.source: In this mode, attempts to upload data without an encryption policy or download data that is not encrypted on the service will fail on the client.
trans-unit.target: In this mode, attempts to upload data without an encryption policy or download data that is not encrypted on the service will fail on the client.

trans-unit.source: The RequireEncryption property of the request options object controls this behavior.
trans-unit.target: The RequireEncryption property of the request options object controls this behavior.

trans-unit.source: If your application will encrypt all objects stored in Azure Storage, then you can set the RequireEncryption property on the default request options for the service client object.
trans-unit.target: If your application will encrypt all objects stored in Azure Storage, then you can set the RequireEncryption property on the default request options for the service client object.

trans-unit.source: For example, set CloudBlobClient.DefaultRequestOptions.RequireEncryption to true to require encryption for all blob operations performed through that client object.
trans-unit.target: For example, set CloudBlobClient.DefaultRequestOptions.RequireEncryption to true to require encryption for all blob operations performed through that client object.

trans-unit.source: Create a BlobEncryptionPolicy object and set it in the request options (per API or at a client level by using DefaultRequestOptions).
trans-unit.target: Create a BlobEncryptionPolicy object and set it in the request options (per API or at a client level by using DefaultRequestOptions).

trans-unit.source: Everything else will be handled by the client library internally.
trans-unit.target: Everything else will be handled by the client library internally.

trans-unit.source: Create a QueueEncryptionPolicy object and set it in the request options (per API or at a client level by using DefaultRequestOptions).
trans-unit.target: Create a QueueEncryptionPolicy object and set it in the request options (per API or at a client level by using DefaultRequestOptions).

trans-unit.source: Everything else will be handled by the client library internally.
trans-unit.target: Everything else will be handled by the client library internally.

trans-unit.source: In addition to creating an encryption policy and setting it on request options, you must either specify an EncryptionResolver in TableRequestOptions, or set the [EncryptProperty] attribute on the entity.
trans-unit.target: In addition to creating an encryption policy and setting it on request options, you must either specify an EncryptionResolver in TableRequestOptions, or set the [EncryptProperty] attribute on the entity.

trans-unit.source: As mentioned above, if the entity implements TableEntity, then the properties can be decorated with the [EncryptProperty] attribute instead of specifying the EncryptionResolver.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned above, if the entity implements TableEntity, then the properties can be decorated with the [EncryptProperty] attribute instead of specifying the EncryptionResolver.

trans-unit.source: Note that encrypting your storage data results in additional performance overhead.
